awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Synthesis, Characterization and Physical Properties of Pr-Based Heavy Fermions
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

In recent years, studies on quantum phase transitions (QPTs) in Ce-based heavy fermion compounds have transformed our understanding of magnetism and superconductivity. This CAREER project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program, will expand our repertoire of heavy fermion materials beyond Ce-based compounds and towards Pr-based materials.  Exploratory synthesis, structural characterization, and magnetic property measurements will be used to determine structure-property relationships that impact crystal-field splitting of the localized Pr3+ ion 4f2-electronic configuration. Efforts will placed on synthesis of single-crystals, which will increase the availability of single crystals in the United States and enable unambiguous determination of crystal structure and physical behavior. Collaborative work in inelastic neutron scattering studies will be conducted to determine structural effects on crystal field splitting as a function of chemical composition, pressure or magnetic field. Investigations of PrAu2-xCuxSi2 and PrAu2Si2-x Gex and the Heusler compounds, PrInT2-xT?x (T, T'= Cu, Ag, Au), will be the foundation for a long-term research program of exploratory synthesis and characterization of PrxTyMz (T = transition metal and M = main-group metal).

This research is integrated into education and outreach activities involving undergraduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and high school teachers.  Undergraduate research experiences will be enhanced by materials chemistry seminars and research opportunities at national laboratories. Postdoctoral researchers will receive comprehensive training by participating in both solid-state chemistry research and undergraduate education.  High school teachers will gain hands-on research and teaching experience in solid-state chemistry during summer research opportunities. 


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Investigations on quantum phase transitions have transformed our understanding of magnetism and superconductivity. This project will expand the current repertoire of quantum phase transition materials towards Praesodynium-based compounds, thereby enhancing our ability to design magnetic and superconducting materials in the future. Emphasis is placed on exploratory synthesis, structural characterization, and physical property measurement of single-crystals of Praesodynium-intermetallic compounds. Crystallography experiments at neutron and synchrotron facilities will be correlated with magnetic, thermodynamic and electrical property measurements. Growth of single crystals will address the deficit of single crystals available for research in the United States. In addition, collaborations between academia and national laboratories will expand single-crystal growth capabilities to University of Northern Colorado, yield more productive synthesis efforts, and engage students and postdoctoral researchers in national laboratory environments. High school teachers will gain hands-on research and teaching experience in solid-state chemistry during summer research opportunities.

por.por_cntn:
The original goal of this project was to investigate structure and unique and exotic magnetic and electrical properties of praseodymium-containing intermetallic compounds. While we did complete work in this area, we realized that some praseodymium-containing chalcogenide compounds also exhibited interesting optical behavior. We also realized that there has been little research reported on the topic of optical properties of rare-earth chalcogenides. Many rare-earth chalcogenides exhibit intriguing optical properties because of their unique f-electron transitions. We therefore broadened our project goal towards these materials in hopes of understanding the potential of rare-earth chalcogenides in photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical applications. This Outcomes Report outlines our significant findings in both areas of intermetallics and chalcogenides.

Rare-Earth Intermetallics

In the area of intermetallic compounds, we discovered new compounds, characterized their crystal structures and measured magnetic and electrical properties. Novel CePd3+xGa8-x phases were obtained by strategically using the flux growth method where gallium metal was employed a flux medium. The structural relationship between these phases were determined from in situ X-ray diffraction experiments conducted at Argonne National Laboratory. The materials showed possible magnetic frustration.

We also studied materials including PrCu0.45Te2, Pr1.33Pt4Ga10, where we grew single crystals of these compounds. Magnetic susceptibility and heat capacity measurements revealed that the f-electrons of Pr3+ may be contributing to local short range magnetic ordering.

Rare-Earth Chalcogenides

Although CaCe2S4 and CaLa2S4 have been previously synthesized, we developed a greener solid-state synthesis method, not necessitating the flow of noxious gases that was used in previous syntheses. We were also the first to measure photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical properties of CaCe2S4. A red-orange rare earth ternary chalcogenide, CaCe2S4, was prepared in powder form by solid-state synthesis.  The optical band gap of CaCe2S4 was determined by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) to be ~2.1 eV, consistent with the observed red-orange color.  Photoelectrochemistry experiments on CaCe2S4 films showed n-type semiconductor behavior.  Thermal analyses suggest the compound to be stable to temperatures as high as ~450 °C, suggesting thermal anneal to be a viable strategy for improving photoelectrochemical performance such that higher photocurrents can be secured.

In CaCe2S4 and CaLa2S4, the Ce3+ ion is expected to contribute one f-electron while La3+ ions contribute zero f-electron density. Because CaCe2S4 and CaLa2S4 share the same crystal structure, a solid solution, Ca(La1-xCex)2S4, is an ideal family of compounds to systematically study the fundamental role of f-electrons in optical properties.  Upon synthesizing this isostructural series, the gradual color change with increasing Ce concentration was obvious to the naked eye. Figure 1 includes photographs of the Ca(La1-xCex)2S4  solid solution. The structure of these materials were studied using neutron and synchrotron sources at Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory. Because La and Ce cannot be distinguished from each other using X-ray sources, the neutron and X-ray diffraction experiments proved to be complementary to each other. Structural analyses and photoelectrochemical property measurements are currently underway.

Broader Impact

The integration of solid-state chemistry education into undergraduate and postdoctoral studies and teacher development programs was an important piece of the grant. This grant involved twelve undergraduate, four Masters students, two high school teachers and two postdoctoral fellows. We also hosted an undergraduate student from Colombia. Five of the undergraduates were considered first-generation, and two of the undergraduate students transferred from community colleges. One undergraduate student traveled to National Institute for Standards and Technology Center for Neutron Research to conduct neutron scattering experiments; this positive experience helped lead her towards a PhD and ultimately a faculty position at a primarily-undergraduate institution. Similarly, postdocs conducted neutron scattering experiments at ILL and the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory to learn pair distribution function analysis. Graduate students have traveled to Summer School on Crystal Growth, attended a Rietveld analysis workshop, delivered oral and poster presentations at numerous regional and national meetings.

Over a dozen student poster presentations at university and nation-wide technical conference and nine peer-reviewed publications resulted from this grant. More than half of the publications include undergraduate and/or high school teacher researchers as co-authors. Undergraduate and graduate students have garnered multiple awards for their oral presentations at the 2017 ACS DFW Meeting-in-Miniature and the Gulf Coast Undergraduate Research Symposium.

Two high school teachers participated in summer research that resulted in peer-reviewed publications with them as co-authors. The teachers also developed instructional material on solid-state chemistry to use in their own classrooms. This is important because solid-state chemistry is often left out of high school curricula.

In addition to research experiences, new coursework was introduced; the PI developed and initiated a graduate level Introduction to Solid-State Chemistry (CHEM 590) and a Characterization of Solids (CHEM 395/590). Both courses were attended by undergraduate and Masters level students. The PI developed CHEM 395/590 with a professor in the Department of Earth Sciences to teach a semester-long course on powder diffraction and electron microscopy.
